sections.In the books:
In the ''[[A Song of Ice and Fire]]'' novels, the Drowned Men carry cudgels of driftwood. They are forbidden from shedding the blood of other [[ironborn]], but this restriction is taken quite literally: they are still permitted to bludgeon enemies to death with driftwood clubs. It is also quite praiseworthy to drown an offending ironborn, as a sacrifice to the Drowned God.

The Drowned Men are not always successful in reviving adherents, however, and a Drowned Man is considered to be very holy indeed if he has failed to revive only one or two men who undergo the ceremony in his career.

The Drowned Men priesthood have no hierarchical organization. However, prestige, time as a Drowned Man, and the number of initiates successfully resuscitated do grant particular Drowned Men a level of authority. At the time of the [[War of the Five Kings]], [[Aeron Greyjoy|Aeron "Damphair" Greyjoy]] is universally held to be the leader of the Drowned Men, who obey his orders without question. He commands great respect from all of the ironborn. However, Aeron wasn't appointed as some kind of high priest; rather he rose to a position of ''primus inter pares'' through general acclamation.
